Decreased renal venous pressure contributes to the cardiorenal syndrome
A disproportionate rise in blood urea nitrogen compared with serum creatinine is a sign of renal hypoperfusion

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes is hospitalized because of progressive exertional dyspnea and orthopnea. Her examination is notable for an elevated jugular venous pressure to the angle of the jaw, pitting peripheral edema with warm extremities, normal blood pressure, and clear mental status. The admission chest radiograph shows cardiomegaly, small bilateral pleural effusions, and vascular engorgement. After 4 days of treatment with a loop diuretic, she appears clinically euvolemic with a JVP of 7 cm H2O. However, the serum creatinine value has risen from 1.6 mg/dL at the time of admission to 2.3 mg/dL. Which of the following statements about this patient’s condition is NOT correct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) The cardiorenal syndrome is characterized by worsening renal function during a heart failure hospitalization, or soon after discharge, despite symptomatic improvement with diuretic therapy and maintenance of adequate intravascular volume. Underlying chronic kidney disease (e.g., associated with diabetes or hypertension) increases the risk of cardiorenal syndrome, as does neurohormonal activation resulting from impaired cardiac output and excessive loop diuretic therapy. Elevated, not reduced, systemic venous pressure appears to be an important contributing factor to the development of cardiorenal syndrome, because venous congestion contributes to elevated intra-abdominal pressure that can impair glomerular filtration. An increase in blood urea nitrogen out of proportion to serum creatinine is a sign of renal hypoperfusion, resulting from low forward CO or intravascular volume depletion because of high doses of intravenous diuretics. The neurohormonal activation accompanying renal hypoperfusion increases proximal sodium and urea reabsorption, while creatinine handling is unaffected, leading to an elevated BUN/creatinine ratio.

choices.text: The right atrium is the most common site of involvement
The vast majority of patients already have metastases at the time of diagnosis
Malignant tumors account for half of primary cardiac tumors
Lymphomas are the most common primary malignancies of the heart

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presented with increasing dyspnea on exertion. He was initially treated for an upper respiratory tract infection; however, his symptoms persisted. A subsequent echocardiogram revealed an intracardiac mass suggestive of a malignant tumor. Regarding primary malignancies of the heart, which of the following statements is TRUE?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Primary cardiac tumors are much less common than metastatic cardiac lesions. Approximately 25% of primary cardiac tumors display malignant characteristics, and up to 75% of these are sarcomas. Primary cardiac lymphomas are the next most common group. The sites of cardiac malignancies, in decreasing order of frequency, are the right atrium, the left atrium, the right ventricle, and the left ventricle. Tumors limited to the myocardium without intracavitary involvement may be asymptomatic or cause arrhythmias or conduction disturbances. Other typical presentations of cardiac malignancies include precordial pain, heart failure, pericardial effusion, tamponade, conduction system disorders, and/or vena caval obstruction. Tumors that involve the right-sided heart chambers may predominantly cause rightsided heart failure. The prognosis of cardiac malignancies is poor, with common survival times of a few weeks to 2 years after diagnosis. Historically, 75% of patients with cardiac sarcoma had evidence of distant metastases at the time of death, but more recent series have shown that only 25% to 50% of patients have metastatic disease at the time of diagnosis, likely owing to earlier detection with improvements in noninvasive diagnostic capabilities

choices.text: Diastolic function is usually impaired to a greater extent than systolic function
The majority of ventricular emptying is less rapid than usual
Left ventricular end-systolic volume is usually increased
Left ventricular ejection fraction is typically reduced

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy has a syncopal event while playing soccer.He has history of young sudden cardiac death in paternal cousin brother.Pulse is Bisferiens and double cardiac apex is noted.On auscultation LV S4 and ejection systolic ejection murmur at erb’s area is present.ECG shows signs of LVH. An echocardiogram is obtained. Which of the following statements about hemodynamic findings on ECHO in patients with this condition is correct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This is a clinical case of HOCM>The echocardiogram demonstrates hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) with asymmetric septal hypertrophy. The most common physiologic abnormality in HCM is not systolic, but rather diastolic dysfunction. HCM is characterized by abnormal stiffness of the left ventricle, which results in impaired diastolic filling. The abnormal diastolic relaxation increases the left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic pressure with subsequent elevations of left atrial, pulmonary venous, and pulmonary capillary pressures. Although the generation of a pressure gradient due to associated subaortic obstruction would imply that LV ejection is slowed or impeded during systole, there is actually rapid ventricular emptying and a normal, or even augmented, ejection fraction in such patients. Hemodynamic studies have confirmed that the majority of LV output is unusually rapid in patients with HCM and is completed earlier in systole than normal, regardless of whether an outflow gradient is present. Thus, the common symptom of dyspnea in this condition is largely due to impaired diastolic relaxation rather than compromised systolic ejection.

choices.text: She should be referred for pulmonary valve replacement
Her risk of sudden cardiac death is low
The presence of tricuspid regurgitation in this case does not influence the risk of developing atrial arrhythmias
She does not require antibiotic prophylaxis prior to dental procedures

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with tetralogy of Fallot presents for routine outpatient evaluation. She had undergone surgical heart repair at age 5 months, including ventricular septal defect closure with a Dacron patch and relief of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction with a transannular patch. She denies shortness of breath or presyncope. Her electrocardiogram demonstrates normal sinus rhythm with intraventricular conducton delay (QRS duration = 190 msec). Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging reveals a low-normal left ventricular ejection fraction, severe pulmonary regurgitation, right ventricular dilatation with moderate right ventricular systolic dysfunction, and moderate tricuspid regurgitation. Cardiopulmonary exercise testing shows that her maximal oxygen consumption is 56% of the predicted value for her age and body surface area. Which of the following statements is correct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Tetralogy of Fallot is the most common cyanotic congenital cardiac defect that presents after the newborn period. Most experts advocate surgical repair in the first 6 months of life to avoid chronic cyanosis and its complications. Although initial operative outcomes are excellent, provided that the ventricular septal defect is adequately closed and right ventricular outflow tract obstruction is relieved, many patients develop progressive pulmonary regurgitation, especially when a transannular patch is used to enlarge the right ventricular outflow tract. The optimal timing to correct this complication with pulmonary valve replacement (PVR) remains uncertain, but it is appreciated that PVR should be performed when there is severe pulmonary regurgitation with substantial right ventricular dilation or dysfunction, even in the absence of subjective dyspnea. In fact, adults with congenital heart disease tend to underestimate their exercise intolerance, underscoring the importance of objective measures of exercise capacity, such as cardiopulmonary exercise testing. Patients with repaired tetralogy of Fallot are at increased risk of sudden death (SD). Although criteria for an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator for primary prevention remain controversial, a QRS width >180 ms and left ventricular dysfunction have been identified as risk factors for SD. Atrial arrhythmias are also common in patients with repaired tetralogy of Fallot; risk factors include left atrial dilation and tricuspid regurgitation. The American Heart Association guideline for the prevention of endocarditis recommends predental antibiotic prophylaxis for patients with repaired congenital heart disease with residual defects at the site of, or adjacent to, prosthetic material (e.g., Dacron patch).

choices.text: Low-molecular-weight heparin can be safely substituted for intravenous unfractionated heparin
A direct thrombin inhibitor, such as Lepirudin, should be substituted for heparin
Intravenous heparin should be continued, because the low platelet count represents a laboratory artifact without clinical significance
Antibodies directed against the platelet glycoprotein IIb/ IIIa receptor participate in this disorder

questions.text: A 54-year-old man was admitted to the hospital because of acute pulmonary embolism. Intravenous administration of heparin was begun. On admission, the platelet count was 223,000/µL. Four days later it fell to 16,000/µL, although the patient remained asymptomatic, without overt bleeding. Which of the following statements regarding this patient’s condition is TRUE?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) This patient has heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), of which there are two forms. Type I HIT is the common, milder form that likely results from non–immune-mediated heparin-induced aggregation of platelets. Platelet counts usually drop within 2 days of therapy but rarely fall below 100,000/µL, and patients do not often develop bleeding complications. In the majority of such cases, heparin can be continued and the platelet count will improve. Type II HIT, which has developed in the patient presented in this question, is the more dangerous form. It produces more severe thrombocytopenia, with levels often <50000. It develops when antibodies form against the heparin-platelet factor 4 (PF4) complex. These antibodies bind simultaneously to the heparin-PF4 complex and to platelet Fc receptors, an action that stimulates platelet activation and thrombosis. The diagnosis can be confirmed by the measurement of anti-heparin/PF4 antibodies. Type II HIT usually becomes manifest for the first time within 4 to 14 days of the initiation of heparin therapy. However, on subsequent exposure, it can present quickly after even small doses of heparin. Therefore, patients with a history of type II HIT should never receive any form of heparin. When type II HIT develops, heparin should be stopped immediately. If further anticoagulation is needed, a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor, such as lepirudin, argatroban, or bivalirudin, can be substituted. Fondaparinux, a synthetic pentasaccharide with anti-factor Xa activity, is another anticoagulant that can be used safely in patients with HIT.3

choices.text: Individuals with obstructive sleep apnea exhibit persistently increased sympathetic activity, even during daytime wakefulness
Obstructive sleep apnea is associated with drug-resistant hypertension and tachycardia.
Positive airway pressure therapy in obstructive sleep apnea is associated with improved health-related quality-of-life and blood pressure
Unlike obstructive sleep apnea, central sleep apnea is not associated with cardiovascular disease

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents for evaluation of excessive daytime sleepiness. His wife has observed his prominent snoring and gasping at night. On examination pulse is 100/min,BP-150/90 mmHg, chest is clear on auscultation.CVS-normal.BMI-35. Which of the following statements regarding sleep-related breathing disorders and cardiovascular disease is NOT correct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) SA is characterized by transient upper airway occlusion that results in partial or complete cessation in airflow leading to hypoxia, sympathetic activation, repeated arousal and wakefulness, and sleep fragmentation. Individuals with OSA demonstrate persistently heightened sympathetic activity, even during daytime wakefulness. This in turn leads to peripheral vasoconstriction and hypertension, as well as automatic tachycardias driven by the augmented sympathetic tone. Continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) is the cornerstone of OSA management and improving nocturnal hypoxia, and reducing sympathetic activity. In contrast to OSA, CSA represents an instability of ventilatory control, resulting in oscillations in ventilation with periodic hyperpnea and apnea. When manifest as Cheyne Stokes respirations, it is associated with advanced heart failure. CPAP is effective in the management of CSA, is associated with decreased sympathetic drive, reduced ventricular afterload, and improvement in left ventricular ejection fraction. CPAP has been shown to improve nocturnal oxygen saturation and 6-minute walk distance in patients with class II to IV heart failure and CSA.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman had a pacemaker inserted 4 years ago for symptomatic bradycardia because of AV nodal disease. She is clinically feeling well and her ECG shows normal sinus rhythm at a rate of 68/min but no pacemaker spikes. Her pacemaker only functions when the ventricular rate falls below a preset interval. Which of the following best describes her pacemaker function?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Ventricular inhibited. Correct Response: Ventricular inhibited The pacemaker described in this patient is functioning in a ventricular inhibited (VVI) mode. In this mode, the pacemaker monitors the intrinsic ventricular activity and only delivers a pacing stimulus when the heart rate falls below the pacemaker’s preset rate (e.g., less than 68/min in this case). If the patient’s natural ventricular activity is sufficient (as in normal sinus rhythm with an appropriate ventricular rate), the pacemaker remains silent and does not fire. This explains the absence of pacemaker spikes on the ECG, as the patient’s intrinsic rate is adequate. Incorrect Responses: (A) Asynchronous This statement is incorrect because asynchronous pacing delivers stimuli at a fixed rate, regardless of the patient’s intrinsic rhythm. Asynchronous pacing does not account for intrinsic cardiac activity and can lead to inappropriate pacing, potentially causing arrhythmias if it occurs during a vulnerable period (e.g., the T wave). The absence of pacemaker spikes in this patient indicates that her pacemaker is responding appropriately to her intrinsic rhythm, which is inconsistent with asynchronous pacing. (B) Atrial synchronous This statement is incorrect because atrial synchronous pacemakers sense atrial activity and synchronize ventricular pacing to follow the atrial depolarization (P wave). This mode is typically used in patients with intact AV conduction but impaired atrial pacing. The absence of pacing spikes and the fact that this patient’s pacemaker is designed to activate only when the ventricular rate falls below a preset value indicate that her pacemaker is not operating in this mode. (C) Ventricular synchronous This statement is incorrect because ventricular synchronous pacing implies that the pacemaker adjusts its pacing based on intrinsic ventricular activity while maintaining a fixed synchronization. In this patient, the pacemaker is inhibited when intrinsic ventricular activity is adequate, which is different from synchronous pacing.

questions.text: A 80 year old male patient presented with new-onset syncope, chest pain and dyspnea on exertion. On examination blood pressure is 110/95 mm Hg. Auscultation of heart revealed a systolic ejection murmur at right second intercostal space, radiating to carotids. Auscultation of the second heart sound at the base might reveal which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Diminished. Correct Response: Diminished This 80-year-old patient with new-onset syncope, chest pain, and dyspnea on exertion, along with a systolic ejection murmur at the right second intercostal space radiating to the carotids, most likely has aortic stenosis. Aortic stenosis leads to obstruction of blood flow from the left ventricle to the aorta, causing an increase in left ventricular afterload and left ventricular hypertrophy. In aortic stenosis, the second heart sound (S2) often becomes diminished because the aortic valve does not close properly due to the stenotic valve, which reduces the intensity of the aortic component (A2) of S2. Additionally, the pulmonary component (P2) may remain normal, but the aortic component is diminished. The overall sound of S2 is therefore reduced, making diminished S2 a hallmark finding in severe aortic stenosis. Incorrect Responses: (A) Accentuated This statement is incorrect because accentuated S2 typically occurs in conditions where there is increased pulmonary pressure, such as pulmonary hypertension, or when there is increased blood flow through the aortic valve, as seen in conditions like aortic regurgitation. In aortic stenosis, the aortic component of S2 is diminished, not accentuated, due to the inability of the stenotic valve to close properly. (C) Normal This statement is incorrect because in aortic stenosis, the aortic component of S2 is usually diminished due to impaired valve closure. A normal S2 would imply that the aortic valve is closing properly, which is not the case in aortic stenosis. (D) Widely split This statement is incorrect because widely split S2 is typically seen in conditions that delay the closure of the pulmonary valve (such as right bundle branch block or pulmonary hypertension) or in conditions where there is increased right ventricular volume. In aortic stenosis, the aortic valve closes later than the pulmonary valve, but this usually results in a diminished S2 rather than a widely split S2.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman has new-onset transient right arm weakness and word finding difficulty symptoms lasting 3 hours. She is also experiencing exertional dyspnea, and had a syncopal event 1 month ago. On examination temperature is 38 C, clubbing is present and spleen is palpable. Her echocardiogram reveals a cardiac tumor in the left atrium, it is pedunculated and attached to the endocardium. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Myxoma. A myxoma is the most common primary cardiac tumor in adults, and the description of the tumor in this case aligns well with the features of a left atrial myxoma. Myxomas are typically pedunculated masses attached to the endocardium, commonly at the interatrial septum in the left atrium. They can cause a constellation of symptoms, including embolic phenomena (e.g., transient ischemic attack or stroke), as described in this patient, as well as obstructive symptoms (e.g., dyspnea or syncope due to impaired blood flow). Systemic symptoms such as fever, weight loss, and clubbing are often due to cytokine release by the tumor. The palpable spleen may result from embolization or chronic inflammation. The clinical picture of transient right arm weakness, word-finding difficulty, and a left atrial mass strongly suggests a myxoma. Incorrect Options: B. Sarcoma Primary cardiac sarcomas are rare malignant tumors that occur less commonly than myxomas. They often present with symptoms of rapid progression due to their aggressive nature, including significant constitutional symptoms and invasive behavior. Sarcomas are typically not pedunculated but rather infiltrative, and they are more likely to arise in the right atrium or pericardium. This patient’s presentation and imaging findings do not fit the typical sarcoma profile. C. Rhabdomyoma Rhabdomyomas are the most common cardiac tumors in children, often associated with tuberous sclerosis. They are exceedingly rare in adults. These tumors are usually intramyocardial rather than pedunculated, and they do not typically cause embolic phenomena. Thus, rhabdomyoma is an unlikely diagnosis in this adult patient. D. Fibroma Fibromas are benign cardiac tumors often found in children, and they are usually intramyocardial. While they may cause arrhythmias or obstructive symptoms, they are not typically associated with embolic phenomena or systemic symptoms such as fever. A pedunculated tumor in the left atrium would not be consistent with a fibroma.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presented with palpitations and dyspnea. There is no past history of heart disease. On examination pulse is 150/min and is regular. BP-150/90 mmHg, lungs are clear on auscultation, CVS-tachycardia, no murmurs. ECG showed saw tooth P wave appearance with atrial rate of 300/min and 2:1 conduction ratio from atria to ventricles. Which of the following drugs is the best intravenous choice for controlling the heart rate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Diltiazem. Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker (CCB) that is highly effective for rate control in atrial flutter, as seen in this case. Atrial flutter is characterized by a sawtooth pattern on ECG with an atrial rate around 300 beats per minute and a typical 2:1 conduction ratio to the ventricles, leading to a ventricular rate of approximately 150 beats per minute. Intravenous diltiazem works by slowing conduction through the atrioventricular (AV) node, reducing the ventricular response rate while maintaining hemodynamic stability. This makes it an excellent choice in this stable patient with no evidence of heart failure or structural heart disease. Diltiazem’s ability to rapidly lower the heart rate while preserving cardiac output ensures symptom relief without significant side effects. Incorrect Options: B. Lidocaine Lidocaine is a class 1b antiarrhythmic that works primarily on ventricular arrhythmias by blocking sodium channels. It has no significant effect on atrial arrhythmias or AV nodal conduction. Therefore, it would not help in controlling the heart rate in atrial flutter, making it an incorrect choice in this situation. C. DC shock Direct current (DC) cardioversion is a treatment option for atrial flutter, particularly in unstable patients or those with symptoms refractory to pharmacologic therapy. However, this patient is hemodynamically stable, making rate control with medications like diltiazem the preferred initial approach. DC shock would be unnecessarily aggressive in this scenario. D. MgSO4 Magnesium sulfate is primarily used in specific arrhythmias such as torsades de pointes or other ventricular arrhythmias associated with prolonged QT interval. It has no established role in atrial flutter and would not be effective for controlling the ventricular rate in this condition.
